0: Vutthisara, a monk from Thailand, founded the temple in 1927. This site is selected as both Indians and Chinese in an area predominantly settled it. It houses a Buddha statue of 15m tall and weighing 300 tonnes.
1: The local INA, influenced by Subhas Chandra Bose, was formed in 1942 with Japanese support, with the aim of liberating India from British.
1 Esplanade Drive, Queen Elizabeth Walk Esplanade Park, near Cenotaph
City Hall (NS25, EW13), Raffles Place (NS26, EW14), Esplanade (CC3)
2: This was the site of sporting activities in the early days and became popular with families. In 1953, as part of the Coronation Celebrations, the seafront promenade was refurbished and renamed Queen Elizabeth Walk.
Junction of Promenade Linking Esplanade Theatres and Queen Elizabeth Walk, Esplanade Park
City Hall (NS25, EW13), Raffles Place (NS26, EW14), Esplanade (CC3)
3: It was here on 9 February 1942 that the Japanese forces suffered a major loss, fighting against the valiant 27th Australian Brigade and the Dalforce.
Kranji Reservoir Park, Kranji Way, near Pavilion area
4: The Battle for Pasir Panjang, where the harbour and British military depots were the coveted gains, marked one of the last battles for Singapore. It lasted from 12 to 14 February 1942.
Kent Ridge Park, beside Car Park B
5: This is one of the surviving gun emplacements in Singapore today. The battery has two 6" 16-ton guns facing south, which aided the Malay Regiment in the Battle for Pasir Panjang by firing high explosive shells at the advancing Japanese troops along the coastals.
Near History Walk, Labrador Nature Reserve
6: This site marks one of many temporary registration centres set up by the Kempeitai (Japanese Military Police) to screen anti-Japanese Chinese.
531 Upper Cross St, Junction of Upper Cross Street and South Bridge Road (Outside DBS Hong Lim Complex)
Chinatown (DT19, NE4), Telok Ayer (DT18), Raffles Place (NS16, EW14), Clarke Quay (NE5), Maxwell (TE18)
7: Trinity Theological College was born out of the camaraderie and spirit of Christianity experienced by the heads of the Anglican, Methodist and Presbyterian Churches when they were interned at Changi Prison during the Japanese Occupation. Founded on 4th October in 1948, it was the first theological college set up to nurture leadership for the churches in Singapore and Malaya.
Dhoby Ghaut (CC1, NE6, NS24), Bencoolen (DT21), Bras Basah (CC2)
8: Victoria Concert Hall (Formerly known as Victoria Memorial Hall)

Designed by colonial engineer, John Bennett, the theatre portion of the Victoria Theatre and Concert Hall was built as a Town Hall in 1862 which housed the Municipal Offices. The Concert Hall was built between 1902 and 1905 in honour of Queen Victoria. The Memorial Hall played a significant role in Singapore's history, serving as a makeshift hospital during World War II and as a venue for the inaugural meeting of the People's Action Party in 1954.
City Hall (NS25, EW13), Raffles Place (NS26, EW14), Esplanade (CC3)
9: Raffles Institution Original Site (Replaced by Raffles City)

The original site of the first school in Singapore, it was founded by Sir Stamford Raffles on 5 June 1823. It was originally known as "The Institution". Now, the original building has been replaced by Raffles City, a shopping mall, located in the Cityhall District, that is also known as Convention Centre and Singapore Luxury Hotels hotspot.
Junction of North Bridge Road and Stamford Road, beside Raffles City
City Hall (EW13, NS25), Esplanade (CC3), Bras Basah (CC2), Bencoolen (DT21), Bugis (DT14, EW12)
10: Established in 1918 by Chinese Immigrants from the Jin Jiang County of southern Fujian Province, it was the headquarters of the Overseas Chinese Mobilisation Council, formed in 1941 to help Singapore's defence against the Japanese.
Outram Park (EW16, NE3, TE17), Maxwell (TE18), Tanjong Pagar (EW15), Chinatown (DT19, NE4)
11: This temple was built by Ceylon Tamils. It began in an attap shed under a champak ("senpaga" in Tamil) tree in 1875, located near the discovery site of a statue of Vinayagar (the deity Ganesha).
12: Queenstown was built in 1960s to meet housing shortage in Singapore after the Second World War. It is Singapore's first satellite town â€“ an estate with amenities to meet residents' needs.
13: This temple was built in 1870 and is one of the oldest Hindu temples in Singapore.
Rochor (DT13), Bencoolen (DT21), Bras Basah (CC2), Bugis (DT14, EW12)
14: Kwan Im Thong Hood Cho Temple

This temple was built in 1884, showcasing a fine example of Chinese temple architecture and traditional craftsmanship. The temple played an important role in providing refuge for the sick, the wounded and the homeless during the Japanese Occupation. It is also of significance to the Buddhist community among Chinese Singaporeans, and is believed to bring worshippers good luck after praying to the Kuan Yin or Avalokitesvara, the Goddess of Mercy.
Rochor (DT13), Bencoolen (DT21), Bras Basah (CC2), Bugis (DT14, EW12)
15: Dragon's Teeth Gate/Batu Berlayar/Long Ya Men

Batu Berlayar ("Sailing Rock") / Long Ya Men ("Dragon's Tooth Gate"), together with a rock on the opposite shore of Tanjong Rimau, formed a gateway to the west of Keppel Harbour. It was blown up in 1848 to widen the harbour's entrance.
8 Port Road, Batu Berlayar Point, near Car Park B, Labrador Nature Reserve
16: This hospital was founded in 1844 by Tan Tock Seng, a philanthropic Hokkien Chinese pioneer, for the poor and destitute. Here, several firsts in Singapore's medical history were achieved. Now, it is a tertiary referral hospital in Singapore, located in Novena. The hospital has 45 clinical and allied health departments, 16 specialist centres and is powered by more than 8,000 healthcare staff.
17: Geylang Serai is a social centre for the Malay community in Singapore. It was originally filled with lemongrass ("serai" in Malay) plantations between the 1890s to early 1900s.
1 Geylang Serai, Main entrance of Geylang Serai Market and Food Centre
18: The Changi Chapel and Museum is a war museum dedicated to Singapore's history during the Second World War and the Japanese occupation of Singapore. It is modelled after St George's Church, one of the numerous churches built by the prisoners of war in Changi during their internment. Containing the well-known "Changi Murals", these were painted as a symbol of hope and faith for prisoners during the Japanese Occupation. It depicted scenes from the Bible, and were painted by Stanley Warren, a Prisoner-of-War.
19: Founded in 1826, this club became the Royal Singapore Yacht Club in 1922 under the patronage of the Prince of Wales, and was renamed the Republic of Singapore Yacht Club in 1967 with the first president of Singapore, Yusof bin Ishak as it patrons.
20: Pondok Peranakan Gelam Club Historic Marker
Singapore's last pondok (communal lodging house) was located here from 1932 to 2000. It served the welfare of Baweanese immigrants from the Gelam province of Indonesia's Bawean Island.
Maxwell (TE18), Telok Ayer (DT18), Chinatown (DT19, NE4), Tanjong Pagar (EW15), Shenton Way (TE19), Outram Park (EW16, NE3, TE17)
21: Built between 1870-75, the Middle Road Church was first known as the Christian Institute. When it was officially inaugurated as the Malay Church in 1894, it became the first Straits Chinese Methodist Church in Singapore.
Rochor (DT13), Bencoolen (DT21), Bras Basah (CC2), Bugis (DT14, EW12)
22: Founded in 1843 by Rev. Benjamin Peach Keasberry, the church is located approximately 350 metres away from Rochor MRT Station, within Singapore's Central Business District. Formerly known as Malay Mission Chapel, Singapore's first company of the Boys' Brigade was formed here on 12 January 1930. From a small company of 12, the Boys' Brigade in Singapore has since grown to a strength of more than 100 companies.
Rochor (DT13), Bugis (DT14, EW12), Bencoolen (DT21), Bras Basah (CC2)
23: Syonan Jinja ("Syonan Shrine") was built in 1942 in memory of the Japanese soldiers who died fighting in the invasion of Built by the Japanese Imperial Army during the Japanese occupation of Singapore in World War II. Ceremonies for significant events were held here until it was destroyed after the war, before British forces re-occupied Singapore. Located deep inside the Central Catchment Nature Reserve (CCNR), the National Heritage Board (NHB) declared the site a historic site in 2002, although no plans have been made public so far to develop or make any significant changes to the site since the war. Singapore.
24: Founded in 1895, it is one of the oldest millionaires club in Singapore. The club was the centre of the Chinese Salvation Movement in Southeast Asia from 1937-1942. Originally located at Duxton Hill, it moved to Club Street before settling at this location in 1952. It supported the 1911 Xinhai Revolution which overthrew the Qing Dynasty, leading to the establishment of the Republic of China. During World War II, it was the headquarters of the anti-Japanese China Salvation Movement in Southeast Asia.
Outram Park (EW16, NE3, TE17), Maxwell (TE18), Tanjong Pagar (EW15), Chinatown (DT19, NE4)
25: This building housed Fuk Tak Chi ("Fu De Ci" in Mandarin), one of the Singapore's oldest Chinese temples, from the 1820s to 1994. It was later converted into a museum.
26: OCBC Bank was born out of the Great Depression through the consolidation of three Hokkien banks in 1932 - the Chinese Commercial Bank Limited (incorporated in 1912), the Ho Hong Bank Limited (incorporated in 1917) and the Oversea-Chinese Bank Limited (incorporated in 1919). It was originally located at China Building which featured a prominent Chinese-style roof and classical elements on its facade.
65 Chulia Street, North Tower OCBC Headquarters
Raffles Place (EW14, NS26), Telok Ayer (DT18), Clarke Quay (NE5)
27: Changi Beach was a massacre site of Sook Ching. The Hojo Kempei (Japanese auxiliary military police) machine-gunned many male civilians on this shore on 20 February 1942. With an estimate of 25000 to 50000 deaths, Sook Ching was a mass killing that occurred from 18 February to 4 March 1942 in Singapore after it fell to the Japanese. It was a systematic purge and massacre of 'anti-Japanese' elements in Singapore, with the Singaporean Chinese particularly targeted by the Japanese military during the occupation.
Changi Beach Park Lamp Post A2-13 (113), Near Car Park 2
28: Adam park estate was the site of intense fighting between British forces and the invading Japanese army in between 12th and 15th February 1942, in the last days before the British surrendered Singapore.
7 Adam Park, junction of Adam Road and Adam Park
29: Opened in 1940, the Alexandra Hospital (former British Military Hospital) served as the principal hospital for Britain's Far East Command during World War II. The hospital was the most-advanced and best-equipped medical institution in Singapore and Malaya. However, it was caught between the advancing Japanese troops and the retreating British forces. It became the site of a Japanese massacre when between 150 and 200 staff and patients were killed on 14 February 1942.
30: The Anglo-Chinese School (ACS) was founded here by Rev. William Fitzjames Oldham in 1886 at a shophouse in Amoy Street. Starting with 13 students, the school aimed to provide an education for the many boys Bishop Fitzjames saw wandering aimlessly in the streets. Today, it has grown to a family of six fine schools [including ACS (Independent), ACS (Junior), ACS (Primary), ACS (Barker Road) and Anglo-Chinese Junior College] in Singapore and ACS (Jakarta) in Indonesia, with a total enrolment of more than 10,000.
31: Balestier Road, from which Balestier Plain takes its name, was named after Joseph Balestier, a keen botanist and agriculturist who arrived in Singapore in 1834. He was appointed as the first U.S Consul in Singapore in 1836 by then President of the United States, Andrew Jackson. Balestier Plain was a vast open space in the early 1900s.The playing fields bounded by Balestier Road from Tessensohn Road to Moulmein Road were known as Balestier Plain. It was associated to eight sports clubs in its vicinity - the Ceylon Sports Club (CSC), the Ceylon Tamils' Association (CTA), the Singapore Indian Association (IA), the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA), the Singapore Chinese Recreation Club (SCRC), the Singapore Khalsa Association (SKA), the Singapore Malay Football Clubs (MFC) and Kamala Club (KC), or collectively known as the Balestier Plain Clubs. Thus, Balestier Plain had then transformed into an area representing the three major races of sports in Singapore. When the Japanese invaded Singapore during World War II, the British stored drums of petrol in the club buildings and bombed these places in defence. After Singapore's defeat, the Japanese built their military barracks on the site and the field of Balestier Plain was later used to grow vegetable garden full of food-producing plants to cope with the scarcity of food. What was left of the field was badly damaged and could no longer be used for sport activities. Balestier Plain did not stay this way for long. It was given back to the citizens in the year 1947 after the liberation of Singapore and work of levelling the plain was completed on August the following year. Once that was completed, government surveyors were deployed to fix up a formation level to ensure that the whole field was one level plain before final touches from the respective clubs made to their own plots of land. At present, Balestier Plain stands as one of the leading recreational zones in Singapore, and continues to produce some of Singapore's top athletes.
Beside Bus Stop No. 50239, Near Ceylon Sports Club
32: Battle of Bukit Timah Historic Marker

One of the fiercest military encounters during WWII took place here as the Bukit Timah area held strategic and tactical importance to the Japanese and the British. This site marks Percival's final defence of southern Singapore against the Japanese invaders from the north on 8 February 1942.
33: Two memorials, one for the Japanese soldiers and the other for Allied Soldiers, built by Australian POWs to commemorate the war dead of the Japanese and the Allies who fought during the decisive Battle of Bukit Timah in Singapore during the Second World War, sat on top on this hill-top. The former was Syonan Chureito, built by 500 Allied Prisoners of War while the latter was a wooden cross that stood behind.
34: Also known as the Wadda Gurdwara, this Sikh temple was the first set up in a bungalow at Queen Street, at 180269, in 1912. The temple is now relocated at Towner Road.
Rochor (DT13), Bencoolen (DT21), Bras Basah (CC2), Bugis (DT14, EW12)
35: Originally known as Deng Xiansheng and his school name Deng Xixian, Deng Xiaoping was born on 22 August 1904 in Guang'an County, Sichuan Province. In 1920, Deng left forÂ studies in France. His six-year stay in France proved to be a turning point in his life.
1 Empress Place, beside Anderson Bridge, on the grounds of the Asian Civilisations Museum
City Hall (NS25, EW13), Raffles Place (NS26, EW14), Esplanade (CC3)
36: Kandang Kerbau Hospital, the birthplace of over 1.2 million Singaporeans, was the largest maternity hospital in the world from the early 1950s to the early 1970s. It was named after the district where it was located. The district around the crossroads formed by Serangoon Road, Selegie Road, Bukit Timah Road and Rochor Road was known in Malay as "Kerdang Kerbau".
37: Kempeitai East District Branch Historic Marker

The original building, the YMCA, was used by the East Branch of the Kempeitai (Japanese Military Police) during the Japanese Occupation. The Kempeitai was the military police of the Imperial Japanese Army from 1881 to 1945. The organization also shared civilian secret police, espionage, and counter-intelligence roles within Japan and its occupied territories, and was notorious for its brutality and role in suppressing dissent. Local anti-Japanese suspects were imprisoned and tortured for information here. The building was pulled down in 1981.
Dhoby Ghaut (NS24, CC1, NE6), Bencoolen (DT21), Bras Basah (CC2), City Hall (NS25, EW13)
38: This is Singapore's second reservoir, constructed after water demand outgrew the capacity of MacRitchie Reservoir. It was known as Kallang River Reservoir when it opened in 1912.
Beside Jetty, Lower Peirce Reservoir Park
39: Singapore's first reservoir was officially opened in 1878 as the Impounding Reservoir, to supply freshwater for the growing population. It has also been a popular place for recreation over the years.
At the foot of Hilltop, Macritchie Reservoir Park
40: On 6 August 1935, businessman Wee Kheng Chiang, together with six other friends, established the bank after raising S$1 million. The bank was named United Chinese Bank (UCB) to emphasise its links to the Chinese population in Singapore. In 1 October 1935, UCB opened for business in the three-story Bonham Building in Raffles Place. Over the years, it got renamed to United Overseas Bank (UOB) and grew to become one of Singapore's leading banks. Now, UOB also owns the tallest building in Singapore, UOB Plaza One.
Raffles Place (EW14, NS26), Telok Ayer (DT18), Clarke Quay (NE5)
41: This is Singapore's first purpose-built civil airport. Completed in 1937, the modern-style terminal building symbolised the rapid civil aviation progress then. The airport ceased operations in 1955 after being relocated to Paya Lebar.
Junction of Kallang Airport Way and Stadium Link, beside gate to Former Kallang Airport
42: Havelock Road Camp / River Valley Road Camp
The area bounded by River Valley Road and Havelock Road was occupied by Prisoner-of-War (POW) camps during the Japanese Occupation. Five thousand POWs lived in dilapidated attap huts here.
43: Clifford Pier was the landing point for sea passengers and immigrants who came to seek a new life in Singapore. It is also known as "Red Lantern Pier" for the red lamps that hung here.
Raffles Place (EW14, NS26), Bayfront (CE1, DT16), Downtown (DT17)
44: Singapore Badminton Hall was built to host international badminton tournaments. In 1962, it was a vote-counting station for the Referendum on Singapore's merger with Malaya, Sabah and Sarawak.
45: This is one of the oldest parks in Singapore. Built in the 1930s, it was a favourite place for families and couples, with facilities such as swimming bays which extended into the sea and food outlets.
46: Pearl's Hill School began in 1876 at Cross Street as the Singapore Chinese Branch School. It was among the first English elementary schools established by the colonial government. The school served as a feeder school for Raffles Institution. By 1885, the school had become known as Cross Street School.
47: In the early 1900s, Singapore grew rapidly and the crime rate rose with the city's expansion. Harold Fariburn - the Inspector - General of Police from 1925 to 1935 - realised that the Police needed a programme of modernisation and expansion. As a result, police stations like the Beach Road Police Station were built around 1930s.
48: Jalan Besar Stadium was Singapore's main football arena until the National Stadium opened. It also hosted various national events, such as Singapore Youth Festival and National Day Parade.
North entrance of Jalan Besar Stadium
Bendemeer (DT23), Lavender (EW11), Jalan Besar (DT22), Farrer Park (NE8)
49: Singapore's third reservoir was constructed in 1920 to meet the increased demand for freshwater in Singapore. The iconic lookout tower was added to the reservoir in the 1960s.
Beside Lookout Tower, Upper Seletar Reservoir Park, Mandai Road Track 7
50: Established in 1820, Omar Kampong Malacca Mosque is Singapore's oldest mosque. In the 1850s, the original timber structure made way for the current building to accommodate the mosque's growing needs.
51: Chui Eng Free School was established here in 1854 by the Singapore Hokkien Huay Kuan. It was the second-oldest private Chinese school and also one of the first free educational institutions in Singapore.
Telok Ayer (DT18), Raffles Place (EW14, NS26), Chinatown (DT19, NE4)
52: Surrendered British Gunners awaiting Japanese internment buried some 300 bullet-ridden corpses washed ashore on Pulau Blakang Mati, now known as Sentosa.
Former Berhala Reping Artillery Post, Serapong Course Road, Course 4, Sentosa Golf Club
53: In the early days of the SAF and Singapore's independence, the Singapore Infantry Regiment and the PDF shouldered the duties of national defence. The Beach Road Army Camp played a significant role in the transformation.
Former Beach Road Camp, South Beach Development
Promenade (CC4, DT15), Esplanade (CC3), City Hall (NS25, EW13), Bencoolen (DT21)
54: This pillbox was located inland to provide fire cover and defence for key installations in Bukit Timah during the Second World War.
Lamp Post 32, near Singapore Island Country Club (Island Location) Entrance
55: This pillbox lay within the area guarded by the 1st Battalion of the Malay Regiment during the Second World War, to protect key installations in the Southern area, such as Alexandra Military Hospital.
Junction of Pasir Panjang Road and Science Park Road, Beside Shell Petrol Station
56: Officially opened on 8 August 1963, this theatre was built to commemorate the attainment of Singapore's self-government in 1959. It was demolished in 1986 due to structural reasons.
Junction of River Valley Road and Clemnceau Avenue, Beside Fort Canning Park
Fort Canning (DT20), Dhoby Ghaut (NS24, CC1, NE6), Clarke Quay (NE5), Bencoolen (DT21), City Hall (NS25, EW13)
57: Established in 1954, Singapore Polytechnic is the first technical institution in Singapore to train skilled labour. The Prince Edward Campus began operations on 3 November 1958 with 2,800 students.
58: United Chinese Library was founded by Dr Sun Yat Sen on 8 August 1910 at North Boat Quay, to spread revolutionary ideas and garner support for Dr Sun's revolution in China.
Fort Canning (DT20), Dhoby Ghaut (NS24, CC1, NE6), Clarke Quay (NE5), Bencoolen (DT21), City Hall (NS25, EW13)
59: This is an arbitrary defence line from Kranji River to Jurong River, placed to check Japanese advance towards the city from the west. The lack of preparation of the Jurong-Kranji Line, and the large area to be covered meant that troops had to be spread out very thinly along the Defence Line. Miscommunication and uncoordinated initiatives at the senior commanding level on 10 February 1942 made the problems worse.
60: Punggol Beach was a massacre site of Sook Ching. Several men were killed by the Hojo Kempei (Japanese auxiliary military police) on this beach on 28 February 1942.
Beside Jetty at Punggol Point Park
61: Singapore Armed Forces Warrant Officers' and Specialists' Club

The British Government built the clubhouse in 1951 for British non-commissioned officers. It was handed over to Singapore Government when the British pulled out in 1969.The SAF WOSE club was formed in 1974 and was formerly known as the SAF NCO Club until it was renamed in 1994.
Former NCO Buildings, South Beach Development
Promenade (CC4, DT15), Esplanade (CC3), City Hall (NS25, EW13), Bencoolen (DT21)
62: Completed in the late 1930s, Johore Battery was part of Singapore's coastal defence system. It comprised three 15-inch guns known as "monster guns".
Cosford Road, Off Upper Changi Road
63: Merdeka Bridge, declared open on 17 August 1956, was constructed to ease traffic congestion. Its name reflects Singapore's aspirations for independence ("merdeka" in Malay) then.
Merdeka Bridge, Nicoll Highway, beside lamp post 88F
64: This temple was built in 1924 on Silat Road (today Jalan Bukit Merah). It was also known as the Police Gurdwara (a Sikh place of worship) as its congregation was mostly made up of Sikh policemen.
Outram Park (EW16, NE3, TE17), Maxwell (TE18), Tiong Bahru (EW17)
65: The First Public Dental School and Public Clinic

Dental Education and modern dentistry in Singapore began here in 1929. The original Clinic and Dental School of the King Edward VII college of Medicine had its beginnings on this site in the Norris Block of the General Hospital. In 1938, the clinic expanded into a purpose-built facility adjacent to Norris Block. The Japanese military occupied the clinic from 1942 to 1945.
Link Bridge between National Dental Centre Singapore and Health Promotion Board
Outram Park (EW16, NE3, TE17), Maxwell (TE18), Tiong Bahru (EW17)
66: This was formerly the home of Chen Wen Hsi, one of Singapore's pioneer artists. Chen's works mixed Western and Chinese traditions, and continued to influence local artists after his demise in 1991.
67: Joseph Conrad, the renowned English master writer, was of Polish origin and travelled to Singapore and south east asia during his seafaring days. He made Singapore and Southeast asia better known to the world through his writings.
Beside Anderson Bridge, on the grounds of the Fullerton Hotel
City Hall (NS25, EW13), Raffles Place (NS26, EW14), Esplanade (CC3)
68: Methodist Girls' School began in 1887 as Tamil Girls' School in a shophouse at Short Street with nine Indian girls. It was the first educational institution for girls established in Singapore by the Methodists.
Junction of Selegie Road and Short Stree, Beside 100 Selegie Road
Rochor (DT13), Bencoolen (DT21), Bras Basah (CC2), Bugis (DT14, EW12)
69: St. Margaret's School was founded by Maria Dyer and began as a girls' home at North Bridge Road in 1842, to rescue girls who were homeless or being sold to slavery. It was taken over by the Church of England Zenana Missionary Society in 1900, but was again renamed in 1949 as St Margaret’s School after Queen Margaret of Scotland.
Dhoby Ghaut (NS24, CC1, NE6), Bencoolen (DT21), Bras Basah (CC2), Rochor (DT13)
70: Built in 1862, Kallang Gasworks was Singapore's first supplier of piped gas. It played an important role in ensuring efficient gas production for Singapore.
Kampong Bugis End, opposite Kallang Riverside Park
71: Raffles Place was designated as Singapore's business centre in the 1822 Town Plan. Singapore's earliest banks, merchant houses and department stores were situated here.
Raffles Place MRT Station, Exit A
Raffles Place (NS26, EW14), Telok Ayer (DT18), Downtown (DT17)
72: From a small gate here, the compassionate sisters of the Convent of the Holy Infant Jesus took in many abandoned infants and children. A replica, named "Gate of Hope", was installed here in 1996.
City Hall (NS25, EW13), Bras Basah (CC2), Bencoolen (DT21)
73: UEL was founded in 1912. It led major construction projects that contributed to Singapore's urbanisation and economic growth, and built many iconic structures including the Former Supreme Court.
River Valley Road Entrance of UE Square
Fort Canning (DT20), Dhoby Ghaut (NS24, CC1, NE6), Clarke Quay (NE5)
74: Phoenix Park was officially constructed in 1949 by the then-British government and used to house key offices during the colonial administration. A famous example is the British spy agency, Security Intelligence Far East, which operated from Phoenix Park. The agency regularly dealt with top secret informationBlock A is shaped like a naval ship at the bequest of the Supreme Allied Commander, Lord Louis Mountbatten.
75: Execution of Captured Rimau Commandos Historic Marker
Operation Rimau ("tiger" in Malay) was the second Allied commando attack on Japanese ships in Keppel Harbour. It failed, and ten commandos were beheaded by the Japanese near Dover and Clementi Roads.
Beside Bus Stop No. 19059, Near NUS U-town Dover Road Entrance
76: Force 136 was a British secret service team that operated in Malaya during the Second World War. One of the agents was Lim Bo Seng, who led Gustavus V Operation in 1943. His grave is in the vicinity.
Beside zig-zag bridge to Pavailion, MacRitchie Reservoir Park
77: Fort Canning Command Centre was the site where Lieutenant-General Arthur Percival and his commanders decided to surrender Singapore to the Japanese on 15 February 1942.
Fort Canning (DT20), Dhoby Ghaut (NS24, CC1, NE6), Clarke Quay (NE5), Bencoolen (DT21), City Hall (NS25, EW13)
78: As the leader of the Vietnamese nationalist movement for nearly three decades, Ho Chi Minh was one of the prime movers of the post-World War II anti-colonial movement in Asia and one of the most influential communist leaders of the 20th century.
Beside Anderson Bridge, on the grounds of the Asian Civilisations Museum
City Hall (NS25, EW13), Raffles Place (NS26, EW14), Esplanade (CC3)
79: Jawaharlal Nehru was an Indian anti-colonial nationalist, statesman, secular humanist, social democrat, and author who was a central figure in India during the middle of the 20th century. Nehru was a principal leader of the Indian nationalist movement in the 1930s and 1940s.
Beside Anderson Bridge, on the grounds of the Asian Civilisations Museum
City Hall (NS25, EW13), Raffles Place (NS26, EW14), Esplanade (CC3)
80: José Protasio Rizal Mercado y Alonso Realonda was a Filipino nationalist, writer and polymath active at the end of the Spanish colonial period of the Philippines. He is considered a national hero (pambansang bayani) of the Philippines.
Beside Anderson Bridge, on the grounds of the Asian Civilisations Museum
City Hall (NS25, EW13), Raffles Place (NS26, EW14), Esplanade (CC3)
81: Keppel Harbour has been a thriving maritime gateway for trade since the late 19th century. During the Second World War, Operation Jaywick successfully destroyed seven Japanese ships here.
Harbourfront Walk End, Promenade between Harbourfront Centre and Vivocity
82: From 1881, Sikh men began arriving in Singapore as part of the Straits Settlement Police’s Sikh Contingent. Along with the Upper Barracks at the top of this hill, this 5-Storey building was completed in 1934 to house the men
Junction of Pearl's Hill and Eu Tong Sen Street, opposite Pearl's Centre
83: Much like other British colonial buildings from the 1940s, Phoenix Park contains semi-detached row houses that sport a monochrome black-and-white look – similar to that of Wessex Estate and Beaulieu House.
84: Seletar Airfield was the British Royal Air Force's main base in the Far East, equipped to protect the Sembawang naval base. Indian Prisoners-of-War were interned here during the Japanese Occupation.
Beside 1 Piccadilly Circus, near Former Seletar Camp Gate, Bus Stop No. 68111
85: The Upper Barracks located on Pearl’s Hill is rich in history and bears reminders of Singapore’s turbulent post-war times and the operations carried out to maintain public order. Built at the same time as the Lower Barracks, the strategic location of the buildings allowed the Police to form a system of surveillance and control over the Chinatown area that was plagued with crime and vice. Located on Pearl’s Hill, the three-storey building overlooked Chinatown in an era when skyscrapers have yet to be constructed in the area.
86: During the Second World War, the last Allied military troop in Malaya withdrew to Singapore through the Causeway on 31 January 1942, after losing Malaya to the Japanese.
Woodlands Waterfront Park, Near Lamp Post 1R-32
87: Yeung Ching School began in 1905 as a private school for Cantonese children. Apart from conducting classes in the day, it offered night classes to children who were poor or overaged.
88: This was the headquarters of Singapore Customs from 1932 to 1989. The building also housed the Film Censor's Office and the Maxwell Road Post Office.
89: This was the headquarters of Singapore Customs from 1932 to 1989. The building also housed the Film Censor's Office and the Maxwell Road Post Office.
90: This was the headquarters of Singapore Customs from 1932 to 1989. The building also housed the Film Censor's Office and the Maxwell Road Post Office.
91: This was the headquarters of Singapore Customs from 1932 to 1989. The building also housed the Film Censor's Office and the Maxwell Road Post Office.
92: This was the headquarters of Singapore Customs from 1932 to 1989. The building also housed the Film Censor's Office and the Maxwell Road Post Office.
